plain: Blade Runner, 2001: A Space Odyssey, and 2001: A Space Odyssey are all considered to be science fiction films, so it is likely that the user enjoys science fiction as a genre. The user also seems to enjoy films with complex plots, as evidenced by the inclusion of Blade Runner, A Clockwork Orange, and Chinatown. The user likely enjoys a variety of musical scores, as evidenced by the inclusion of films with very different musical styles, such as the orchestral scores of Blade Runner and 2001: A Space Odyssey, the rock opera of Pink Floyd—The Wall, and the punk rock of Repo Man. The user seems to enjoy a wide range of moods in their musical scores, from the somber and reflective to the energetic and rebellious. The user appears to enjoy films set in a variety of different time periods and locations, as evidenced by the inclusion of films set in the future (Blade Runner), the past (The Nightmare Before Christmas, James and the Giant Peach, Dr. Strangelove, Wizard of Oz, Notorious, Alice in Wonderland, and Double Indemnity), and in outer space (2001: A Space Odyssey). The user seems to enjoy a variety of visual styles, from the realistic to the fantastical. The user appears to enjoy a variety of writing styles, from the straightforward to the experimental. The user seems to enjoy films with a runtime of varying lengths, as evidenced by the inclusion of films that range from under 90 minutes (The Nightmare Before Christmas, James and the Giant Peach, Repo Man) to over 3 hours (Blade Runner, 2001: A Space Odyssey, A Clockwork Orange). The user appears to enjoy films that explore a variety of themes, such as identity (Blade Runner), morality (A Clockwork Orange), and the nature of reality (2001: A Space Odyssey).
